source.author: Conran, J.G.
source.title: Liliaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: Modified from: Conran, J.G. (1994). Liliaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Plants not twining, flowering stems erect; flowers in umbels
Plants twining, prostrate or ascending on other vegetation; flowers solitary
Plants leafy (although leaves sometimes withered at time of flowering); scape slender, not branched below inflorescence; roots with fleshy tubers
Plants leafless; scape rather rigid, usually branched well below inflorescence; roots arising from a thick, knotty rhizome
Inflorescence slender, little or not branched, with sessile umbels along scape; leaves tenuous, usually withered at time of flowering; tubers long-fusiform; north-west only
Inflorescence a rather broad panicle of several pedunculate umbels; leaves prominent at time of flowering; tubers ovoid; widespread, but not in north-west
All umbels in inflorescence terminal; perianth segments mostly <12 mm long; damp heathlands of far eastern Victoria
Sessile subterminal umbels present, the inflorescence consequently appearing racemose; perianth segments 12 to 15 mm long; heath and mallee communities of western Victoria
